Rusty Harold writes:

> Don't do this directly. All unit tests should pass =
through 
> the public (and protected) interfaces of a class. Most code 
> t=
hat can't be reached through the public/protected interfaces 
> is unreacha=
ble code and should be deleted rather than tested. 

I believe this is not =
only a radical advice, it actually goes against the
idea of unit testing.  =
What you are describing is acceptance testing, not
unit testing.

Unit test=
ing allows you to test very small portions of code in order to
catch failur=
es as soon as possible.  If all you test is public/protected
methods, you w=
ill miss an opportunity to catch a bug in a very fundamental
piece of your =
code and you will be wasting time looking for it.

For example, imagine you=
 are writing a file manager that can list your files
in several orders (by =
date, by name, etc...) and therefore, makes use of
several types of algorit=
hms, all private.  One day, the program starts
showing the files in the wro=
ng order.

The sort algorithm is not exposed to anyone, but if you unit-tes=
t it, you
will catch the error much earlier instead of starting to investig=
ate, say,
your list widget.

Don't be dogmatic about testing:  test whateve=
r you think can break.  And
it's okay if it includes private methods.
